characters: EXT. IN FRONT OF ORRIN'S HOUSE. A MOMENT LATER
EXT. MAIN STREET. A FEW MOMENTS LATER
INT. LIVING ROOM. A FEW MOMENTS LATER
EXT. THE PRESCOTTS' FRONT DOOR. NIGHT
EXT. SCOTTSVILLE CEMETERY. SIXTEEN YEARS LATER. DAY
EXT. THE HOUSE. A MOMENT LATER
INT. BRIAN'S OFFICE. A MOMENT LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shifting lights from the odd passing car play over th faces of MR. and MRS. PRESCOTT, a pleasant-looking couple their late thirties, dressed up for a night out. Mr. Pres drives them along a dark hilly two-lane highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do they always put braces on  teenage girls at the exact moment  when they're the most self-conscious  about their appearance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UP AHEAD, near the top of the oncoming hill, a RED PICKUP TRUCK is poking its nose out of the short exit lane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PICKUP LURCHES into the road, with not nearly enough  time to spare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Prescott swerves OVER the DOUBLE SOLID WHITE LINE and clears the truck as -- Another pair of HEADLIGHTS from an oncoming truck RISES U over the HILL directly in FRONT of them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Screams) Tom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Prescott's FOOT STOMPS on the BRAKE. We BLACK OUT and there is the SOUND of a terrible CRASH.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE PRESCOTTS' FRONT DOOR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The SHADOW of a big man looms up onto the front door. A b finger RINGS the BELL. A moment. AMY, a thirteen-year-old baby-sitter with braces, opens t door and looks up. In the b.g. we see TWO CHILDREN, SAMMY (Samantha) and TERRY PRESCOTT, in their pajamas, lying on their stomachs in the living room, watching television. S is eleven. Terry is eight. REVERSE: DARRYL, the SHERIFF, a portly fellow with glasse and a mustache, looks down at AMY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Amy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Puzzled) Hi, Darryl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Thinking) Amy, would you please tell the kids  you'll be right back, and then shut  the door and come outside to talk to  us for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. (To kids) Be right back, you guys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not supposed to go out, Amy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's going to smoke a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMY closes the door and looks expectantly up at Darryl. D doesn't know how to start.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHURCH. DAY
dialogues.text: CREDITS BEGIN OVER a blustery April day. The steeple of t little white church stands out against the sharp blue sky

dialogues.speaker: INT. TOWN CHURCH. DAY
dialogues.text: It's a small church and a small congregation, but it's fu There's a CHOIR of mostly SENIOR CITIZENS arrayed in the  back. TWO CLOSED CASKETS are laid out in front of the  MINISTER, a fiftyish woman with thick glasses and salt-an pepper hair, who is giving a eulogy MOS. Among the mourners in the second row sit Terry and Sammy, both redeyed, and uncomfortable in their dress-up clothes Their Aunt Ruth, a pinch-faced woman in her forties, sits next to them. Sammy and Terry are holding hands tightly. Terry wipes hi eyes with his free hand. The Minister addresses her remarks to the children. Sammy hanging on the Minister's every word; Terry is shifting h eyes and his seat as if it will kill him to sit still ano minute.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SCOTTSVILLE CEMETERY. SIXTEEN YEARS LATER. DAY
dialogues.text: On the beautiful hill overlooking the beautiful windy gre country, SAMMY, twenty-seven years old now, puts flowers her parents' graves with quick, practiced movements. She is a nice-looking young woman of a neat appearance, s from primness by an elusive, pleasantly flustered quality An unsuccessfully neat person. She is dressed in office  clothes -- white blouse, dark skirt, high heels, light  raincoat over everything. She picks out a couple of weeds and then bows her head and closes her eyes. CREDITS END.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scottsville is a small town. Main Street. Run-down old st next to a new bank, a couple of chain stores, a few  restaurants of varying ambitions. Civil War statue. World War I statue. World War II statue. Residential streets  wandering away from Main Street up and down hills. You kn there's a minimall somewhere nearby. A fair amount of act during the daytime. SAMMY'S CAR pulls up across the street from where an eigh year-old BOY in a secondhand baseball jacket and a school knapsack is waiting at the curb. This is her son, RUDY. S calls out the car window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy, come on! I'm really late!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy hurries across the street and gets in the car, sling his knapsack into the backseat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're supposed to write a story for  English homework, but they didn't  tell us what it's supposed to be  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean they didn't tell us what it's  supposed to be about. They said do  whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. I just think it's  unstructured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiles) Well, I'm sure you'll be able to  think of something. If you can't,  I'll help you.

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. CAR/CAROL'S HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Sammy stops the car outside a heavily THICKETED DRIVEWAY  (CAROL'S HOUSE), and RUDY gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget your backpack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy returns to take his knapsack out of the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a backpack, it's a knapsack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget your knapsack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy hoists his knapsack out of the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy gives her a kiss and puts his arms around her and  squeezes her neck. He withdraws, slams the door. As Sammy DRIVES AWAY, he sl up the long twisting driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy gets out of her car, which is parked in one of the  half dozen spaces in the little parking lot allocated for bank employees. She hurries toward the employees' entrance, fixing her sk as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERCHANTS NATIONAL TRUST. DAY
dialogues.text: Sammy hurries down the clean hallway in the back past MAB a pleasant-faced fellow employee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess who's been asking for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mabel nods and passes by. SAMMY KNOCKS on a big door that says "Manager" and has ha the letters of the previous branch manager's name taken o it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Inside) Yeah, come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy swings open the door. BRIAN EVERETT, the new branch manager, is unpacking a box. Sammy is surprised to see he in his early thirties and very good-looking in a boyish s of way; he wears shirt-sleeves and tie, and a wedding rin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Everett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah: Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian. Hi. I'm Samantha Prescott --  I'm the lending officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, hi, how are you? Come on in.  Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy comes into the office and sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am so sorry I was late...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we missed you before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got held up. Believe me, it is not  something I make a habit of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it's not. Actually -- could  you just, could you close that door  for me? Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy gets up and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BRIAN'S OFFICE. LATER
dialogues.text: Sammy sits in front of Brian's desk. Brian is behind the  desk listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- so I always just run out at 3:15  to pick him up and then run him real  quick over to the sitter's house.  Anyway, Larry never minded about it  and I was just hoping it would be OK  with you too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- Samantha -- I realize that  Scottsville is not exactly a major  banking center...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I know it's not... But it's  kind of a personal challenge to me  to see what we can do to bring local  service up to the same kinds of  standards we'd be trying to meet if  we were the biggest branch in the  state. And that means I don't want  anybody running out at 3:15 or 3:30,  or whenever the bus happens to come  in that day. Now is there anybody  else who can pick your son up after  school? Does your husband work in  the area? Do you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- No -- Rudy Sr. isn't "on the  scene." So to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can give you a couple of  days to make some other arrangement,  but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- Brian? I understand what  you're saying, and I think it's great.  I do. Because there's a lot of things  around here that could use some  attention. Believe me. But I've  honestly been meeting that bus every  day for four years now and it really  does take just fifteen minutes, and  if I take the time out of my lunch  hour...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd really prefer it if you would  make some other arrangement. OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Brightly) I'll do my best...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian kicks back in his chair and puts his hands behind h head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old's your son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a terrific age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy and Rudy drive home in silence. The orange sunlight flickers through the trees and onto their faces as they d along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same house that Sammy grew up in, with sixteen years' more wear on it. Sammy's car swings expertly by the mailbox, and Rudy reac half his body out of the passenger window and gets the ma

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S HOUSE. DUSK
dialogues.text: Sammy comes into the house carrying two bags of groceries Rudy follows, looking through the mail. Sammy passes thro the house and goes into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a letter from Uncle Terry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her whole face lights up and she grabs the letter. She te it open and reads it with growing excitement.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S BEDROOM. LATER
dialogues.text: Sammy opens her FILE DRAWER. Inside are tax files, househ files, miscellaneous files. She puts Terry's letter away in a very full file marked " Correspondence." The folder is stuffed with other letters on all different kinds of stationery from all over the  country, all from Terry.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy and Rudy are eating dinner. It's a biggish house fo just two people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose room is he gonna stay in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can stay in the little room. (Pause) But you know what? He's not going to  live here. He's only gonna stay for  a little while... And it's OK if you  don't remember him, because you were  only six the last time he was here...  But it'll be nice if you got a chance  to get to know each other a little  bit. Don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy looks worried and doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. LATER
dialogues.text: Rudy is on the floor, writing in his school composition  notebook. Sammy comes downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy? Would it distract you if I put  on some music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts on a CD, sits down and picks up a book. She look at Rudy, who is writing away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you think of a story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a made-up story about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I read it when you're done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy keeps writing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. LATER
dialogues.text: Sammy is smoking a cigarette and drinking a glass of wine and reading Rudy's story. It upsets her.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S BEDROOM. LATER
dialogues.text: Sammy sits on the edge of her bed, not dialing the phone. She catches a glimpse of herself in her parents' floor-le mirror with the worn, heavy wooden frame. Against her bet judgment she picks up the phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DAWSON'S GRILL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy and BOB STEEGERSON are eating dinner at Dawson's, t only fancy restaurant in town. Bob is in his mid-thirties Realtor, a decent, ordinary guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, Bob, it's sort of this  adventure story, and Rudy's father  is this secret agent or something,  working for the government... And it  just made me feel weird. You know?  Because I never really say much to  him about Rudy Sr., because I don't  know what to say. And I don't know  whether I should just let him imagine  whatever he wants to imagine, or  whether I should sit him down sometime  and tell him, you know, that his  father is not such a nice person.  You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I don't know, Sammy. What  have you told him already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much. He knows I don't have the  highest opinion of him. And he knows  I don't want to see him or know  anything about him, ever. But I tried  to keep it kind of neutral. Anyway...  I could go into a lot more detail,  believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... It's an interesting problem.  But I don't really know what to tell  you... It's a little outside my  personal field of expertise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be glad to give it some thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is smiling at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing... I'm just glad to see you...  I'm glad you called me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you were surprised...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um -- a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob drains his wineglass. Sammy cuts at her steak.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOB'S BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy and Bob lie in Bob's bed, a few minutes after havin made love. They are very far away from each other, but tr with difficulty not to let on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should get going...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I've got the baby-sitter...  But... Thanks for a lovely evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him. She tries to make it sexy, but he's not i it anymore and he politely restricts the kissing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S BATHROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy stands in her slip brushing her teeth in front of t mirror. She brushes vigorously, looking at herself while brushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corner window of a grim little apartment building on very grim street in a grim little city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny apartment with a bed, chair, table, fridge, and no much else. One window has a broken pane and an old sheet  neatly thumbtacked over it to keep the wind out. TERRY PRESCOTT comes in. He is twenty-five years old: a r mess with a certain natural appeal. He wears old jeans, v old hiking boots, and a lumberjack-style coat. He takes a wool hat off his head. His hair is longish and dirty. SHEILA SADLER is sitting at the table by the fridge. She barely eighteen, frail and damaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Terry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry looks at her and smiles encouragingly. She smiles b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you get the hat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I got it on the street for a  dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know, it's pretty much  your standard woolen hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I had a very similar reaction  to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheila looks away. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get that money from you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she opens her purse, Terry takes a few vague steps tow her. She takes out a tiny hippie-ish woven wallet and giv Terry all the money in it: a twenty and two ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you borrow some cash from your  brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, yeah, but that would involve  speaking to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm definitely gonna be gone  for a couple of days at least, Sheila.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you have to stay so long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because my sister is not a bank, you  know? I can't just show up and ask  her for --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem to think my brother's a  bank!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Sheila can we just cut out the  puerile crap?! I'll be back just as  soon as I can. OK? I am not the kind  of man that everyone says I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you wanna tell me you love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was really convincing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I think after this is over  you should seriously consider moving  back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Short laugh) Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Gives up) All right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna call tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her arms around him and holds on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wide open shot of hilly country and a big sky overhead. A GREYHOUND BUS drives into the shot along the curve of the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry is seated on the toilet seat in the cramped bathroo smoking a joint. He takes a huge hit and holds it in for long as humanly possible. He blows out what's left, takes another equally huge hit and holds it in.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LOCAL HIGHWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: The BUS WHOOSHES along a smaller, heavily wooded roller- coaster road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry looks out the window at the passing scenery. The  sunlight flickers on his face. POV TERRY: The bus rolls past the hilltop cemetery. Terry shifts uncomfortably in his seat. POV TERRY: THE "WELCOME TO SCOTTSVILLE" SIGN whizzes by.  Houses start dotting the side of the road. Terry starts getting very agitated.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: Terry stands at one end of Main Street, backpack over his shoulder, as the BUS DRIVES OFF. He looks around at the t going about its Saturday afternoon business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud country-western music is blaring as Sammy, wearing a apron, sets a big vase of flowers on the kitchen table an hurries to the oven. There are also cookies, a pie, evide of massive fancy cooking. She puts on her oven mitts and  takes a lasagna out of the oven, as the phone rings. She  picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into phone) Hello?... TERRY!...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SAMMY'S HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Sammy practically bursts out the front door. She has chan into nice clothes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALLEY. DAY
dialogues.text: Terry secrets himself in a small dark alley. He takes out his carefully wrapped half joint and lights it. SMOKING, looks at the sunlit slant of street beyond the alley.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN STREET. A FEW MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Terry, fairly well stoned, walks along Main Street. A ski man emerges from his hardware store to greet Terry and sh hands. Terry says "Hi," but keeps on walking. He passes s other people. He almost runs right into SHERIFF DARRYL, sixteen years f and grayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff recognizes Terry and breaks into a big smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn! Terry Prescott! How you  doin'? Gimme a cuddle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff gives Terry a big bear hug. Terry is wasted a selfconscious but smiling. He pats the Sheriff's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doin', Darryl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way you headed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just goin' to see Sammy at  Dawson's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I walk with you a little?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, yeah --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Sammy says you been out in  Alaska...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was workin' out there for a  little while...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN STREET. A FEW MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: The Sheriff walks along with Terry. Terry, very self-cons about smelling like pot, fumbles to light a cigarette. Th Sheriff does not seem to notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Sammy says she's gettin' postcards  from all across the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I've been all over the place...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop outside Dawson's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's good to have you back  here, I'll tell you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Darryl. Keep enforcing the  peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that'll be a little harder now  that you're home, but I'll do what I  can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, man, I'm reformed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Good to see you, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Darryl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darryl walks away. Terry stands outside the restaurant lo for Sammy. Behind him in the restaurant Sammy is sitting at a table, talking to the waitress. She sees Terry and gets up immediately, smiling like craz as she threads her way through the tables toward the door Terry turns and sees her. He breaks into a big smile, tos his cigarette and goes into the restaurant. Through the w we see them make their way toward each other. Sammy throws her arms around him. He hugs her back with a big involuntary smile as the GLASS DOOR slowly CLOSES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry is studying the menu, over-intently. Sammy is beami at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about yesterday --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was studying the bus description...  and I just... I got on the wrong bus --  I mean I missed my stop --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care, Terry. I'm just so  glad to see you...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad to see you too, Sammy. Um...  are you coming from work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, no, it's Saturday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, no, it's just... you're dressed  so formally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. No. You know, I just thought I'd --  You know I thought it was a special  occasion... which it is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's good. I thought I'd dress  up too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures to his shitty clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's OK. You look fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A strange,  unsuccessful joke) Yeah, this is the haute cuisine of  garments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, nothing... Um... So how are  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Rudy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're fine, Terry. How are you? (Pause) I mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Where have you been lately, Terry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I know, I haven't been --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a postcard from you from  Alaska...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was up there for a while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that was in the Fall, Terry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know I've been out of touch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a little worried. (Pause) I mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I been a lotta different places...  Um... I went down to Florida for a  while... I was doing some work in  Orlando... I've been all over the  place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I just wish you would have  let me know you were OK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I didn't realize it'd been so  long...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Beaming again) Are you gonna stay in town for a  while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know... I got all these  things I gotta do back in Worcester...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yeah, so I'm probably not gonna  be able to stay more than a day or  so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Well... That's all right...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm kind of trying to keep to a  schedule of sorts. It's a long and  worthy story but I won't trouble you  with it right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He twists around and looks all over the restaurant. She  watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you expecting someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would I be expecting here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just keep looking around, that's  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I was just wondering if we could  get some more refreshments, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs. Looks down. Silence. He looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've actually got to confess to you,  Sammy... that the reason you may not  have heard from me for a little while  is that I've been kind of unable to  write... on account of the fact that  I was in jail for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of people in the restaurant look at them. Terry  notices but Sammy does not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I did a little time, I guess,  in Florida. For, uh, just for  bullshit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just bullshit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do anything. Does it occur  to you that maybe I was wronged?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, could I please --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you please let me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- What happened?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got into a fight in a bar down in  Florida. Which I was not the one who  instigated it, at all. But they worked  up all this bullshit against me and  they threw me in the pen for three  months. I didn't write you because I  didn't want you to get all upset  about it. I just figured you'd figure  I was on the road for a little while.  I know it was stupid and I'm sorry.  I really didn't mean to make you  worry. But you know what? I can't  run around all the time doin' stuff  or not doin' stuff because it's gonna  make you worry! Because then I come  back here, and I tell you about my  fuckin'... traumas, and I get this  wounded little "I've Let You Down"  bullshit, over and over again, and  it really just -- cramps me! Like I  just want to get out from under it!...  And here I am back in this fuckin'  hole explaining myself to you again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK -- Can you please stop cursing at  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I realize I'm in no position  to, uh, basically say anything, ever --  But it's not like I'm down there in  some redneck bar in Florida having  an argument with some stripper's  boyfriend and I suddenly think, "Hey!  Maybe this'd be a good time to really  stick it to Sammy and get myself  locked up for a few months."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too, man. I mean "welcome home."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- You don't write me for six  months, I have no idea where you are --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I don't know if you're alive or  dead --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and then you show up out of nowhere  and tell me you were in jail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm sorry, I'm sorry,  Sammy, I'm really sorry...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patrons are all either looking at them or trying not look. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... I'm in the midst of a slight  predicament...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you need? Money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... Yeah... I'm broke. I gotta get  back to Worcester tomorrow. I got  this girl there, and she's kind of  in a bad situation...? I just need  to borrow some money. Whatever you  can spare. (Pause) I'll pay you back... I'll pay you  back, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really wish Mom was here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do I, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody knows what to do with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how they feel, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence, except for the sounds of the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry? Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (With some difficulty) Well -- I mean, do you ever go to  church anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Sammy, can we not talk about  that shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um -- No, Sammy. I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you tell me why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, yeah. Because I think it's  ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- can you tell me without like,  denigrating what I believe in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I think it's primitive, OK?  I think it's a fairy tale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I mean, have you ever  considered that maybe that's part of  what's making things so difficult  for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- That you've lost hold of -- well,  not just your religious feeling, but  lost hold of any kind of anchor, any  kind of trust in anything... I mean  no wonder you drift around so much.  What could ever stop you? How would  you ever know if you had found the  right thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh, I'm not really looking for  anything, man. I'm just, like, trying  to get on with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WAITRESS approaches with their salads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sets them down on the table. SAMMY and TERRY Thank you. The WAITRESS leaves. Silence. Terry picks at his salad. S doesn't touch hers. She watches him miserably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry watches while Sammy inserts her card in the ATM and punches in her code. Terry waits. She punches in $300. Th machine grinds out her cash. She gives him the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Sammy... I'm really gonna  pay this back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes her card back and puts it back in her wallet.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: Sammy and Terry get in the car. Sammy isn't saying anythi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To pick up Rudy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts on her glasses and her seat belt. She won't look him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... do you not even want me to  visit now? 'Cause I can catch the  bus at five o'clock if that's what  you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, of course I want you to visit,  you idiot! I've been looking forward  to seeing you more than anything!  I've been telling everyone I know  that you were coming home! I cleaned  the whole fucking house so it would  look nice for you! I thought you  were gonna stay for at least a few  days! It didn't occur to me that you  were just broke again. I wish you  would have just sent me an invoice!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops. Terry is now totally contrite.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BATHROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Terry sits in the tub. Water drips from the faucet. He is staring blankly up at the pristine blue-and-white tiled w and the neatly folded matching towels.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. LATER
dialogues.text: Sammy and Rudy are in the living room. Rudy is playing wi a Game Boy type game. In the b.g., TERRY is dialing the P He looks clean and shaved, his hair is neatly combed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into phone) Hi, is that Malcolm?... Hi, this is  Terry Prescott?... I been trying to  get ahold of Sheila and there's no  answer, and I was just wondering if  she -- She what?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into phone) When?... Well -- Is she all right?...  Well, could I talk to her?... Well,  could you give her a message that I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLICK. He is hung up on. He slowly HANGS UP. Sammy notices that something's wrong. He looks at her fro across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That girl I'm with tried to kill  herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tried to kill herself.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TERRY'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Terry is sitting on the bed, addressing an envelope to SH He puts the $300 in the ENVELOPE and seals it. He sees Sa standing in the doorway. He starts to unlace his boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have everything you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy comes into the room and sits next to him. He is ver busy with his laces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Send the money I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should stay home for a  little while, Terry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe that'd be a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts crying. Sammy pats him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SCOTTSVILLE CHURCH. DAY
dialogues.text: A bright, clear, blue-skied Sunday morning in Scottsville Inside the little white church they're singing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHURCH. DAY
dialogues.text: People are filing out of the church. We also see a couple the bank employees, including BRIAN and his very pretty s months' PREGNANT wife, NANCY. We find SAMMY and RUDY. Sam is chatting to some neighbors. Rudy is bored out of his m waiting for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry is lying on the sofa, smoking, with his feet up and boots on, watching Sunday morning TV. On the coffee table are his dirty ashtray, dirty bowl and spoon, Rice Krispie box and a milk carton.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SAMMY'S HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Crickets buzz loudly outside the house.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STAIRS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy, in her bathrobe, comes down the stairs into the li room. Terry is on the sofa playing with Rudy's Game Boy. barely looks up when she speaks to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to bed. Do you have  everything you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry, I'm really glad you're home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry tries to smile at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too, Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes back to his game. She hesitates, then heads back the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Sammy, Terry and Rudy sit at the kitchen table. Sammy is  dressed for work. Rudy is dressed for school. Terry is al fully dressed, drinking the last dregs of a mug of coffee He is tired, but listening to Sammy very carefully, as if receiving difficult and critical instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. So we'll drop Rudy off at the  bus, then all you have to do is drop  me off at the bank, and just pick  Rudy up at 3:30 in front of town  hall, and drive him over to Carol's  house. And that's it. She's on Harvey  Lane, right past where the Dewitts  used to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy knows where she lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry glances at Rudy, then back at Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy walks past MABEL'S DESK, carrying a big stack of fi She drops three of them on the desk. MABEL is typing away her PC. The colors are a garish PURPLE background with GR letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, Mabel, don't those colors hurt  your eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, they keep me fresh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy proceeds down the hall and into --

dialogues.speaker: INT. BRIAN'S OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: Brian is at his desk, busy working between stacks of pape She knocks on the open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! (Looks up) Hi, Sammy. What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, Brian? Did you want us to turn  this time sheet in at the end of the  day, or do you want it at the end of  the week...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, end of the day'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems like an awful lot of extra  paperwork...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian hesitates, shrugs and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy looks at him with a blank smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy sits down at her desk and notices the time: 3:30. S reaches for the phone, then decides not to call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CLOCK on the front of the TOWN HALL reads 3:31. The SCHOOL BUS pulls up across from the town hall and  disgorges a handful of kids. Rudy comes out with his knap looking around... POV RUDY: Terry, across the street, sits on the hood of  Sammy's car, smoking. Rudy walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You showed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry and Rudy drive in silence. Terry glances at Rudy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put on your seat belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It pushes on my neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It pushes on my neck. It's  uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, when somebody slams into us  and you go sailin' through the  windshield, that's liable to be  uncomfortable too. So put on your  seat belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy puts on his seat belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom's parents died in a car accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. They're my parents too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah. Your mom is my sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that means we have the same  parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive in silence for a moment. Terry glances down at Rudy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy, laden with files, plops down at her desk as Mabel passing by. Mabel puts a phone message down in front of h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um -- Carol just called. She said  Terry and Rudy never showed up at  her house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to be kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MOMENT LATER: Brian, talking to an employee, sees Sammy across the bank, hurrying out the employees' exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Sammy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy doesn't hear and exits.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ORRIN'S BACKYARD. DAY
dialogues.text: Terry and Rudy are banging nails with RAY, a young guy Te age. Terry, hammering with swift, accurate blows, glances and watches Rudy for a second. Rudy is hammering away wit no great skill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves Rudy's hand down toward the end of the handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hold it further down, you're  gonna get a lot more power. You should  be able to put that nail down with  two or three hits. Look:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With two swift strokes he drives the nail flush into the  wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the way I hold it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the way you hold it is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't I just do it my own way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry looks at him unsympathetically for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shrugs) You can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes back to work. Rudy resumes hammering. After a mom he switches his grip and starts hammering Terry's way. Te looks up and watches him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. IN FRONT OF ORRIN'S HOUSE. A MOMENT LATER
dialogues.text: Sammy pulls up, fast, and gets out of the car. Hearing th hammering from the backyard, she walks quickly around the side of the house and stops short when she sees Rudy hamm happily away with Terry and Ray. She watches them working, unobserved, with mixed annoyanc and relief, and finally with quiet pleasure, because it's very cheerful sight.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BANK. DAY
dialogues.text: Half the staff has gone home. Sammy, in her coat, picks a NOTE up off her CHAIR. It reads:

dialogues.speaker: INT. BRIAN'S OFFICE. A MOMENT LATER
dialogues.text: Sammy stands in front of Brian's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian? Did you want to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I was kind of wondering what  happened to you today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- Didn't Mabel -- I had a false  alarm about my son...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I kind of thought you were  gonna work that out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I did work it out -- more or  less --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why're you running outta here  in the middle of the day without a  word of explanation to me, Sammy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian, don't yell at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm -- I'm not yelling. I'm just  gettin' a little frustrated here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well Brian:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, could you close the door  please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy, Terry and Rudy sit at dinner. The atmosphere is li and cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And Eddy Dwyer lives in Buffalo,  with his wife and two sons, if you  can believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is depressing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just never struck me as the  marrying type, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wild kids we used to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you a wild kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not compared to your Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy is amazed. Terry looks at him like, "Told you so."

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy is asleep in bed.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RUDY'S BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Rudy is asleep in bed.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Terry sits at the bar, drinking beer. There are a few loc in the place, but it's pretty dead. He looks around; his  energy is too restless for the near-empty bar.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RUDY'S BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The DOOR OPENS, and TERRY COMES IN, smoking a cigarette.  He's plastered. He looks around the room. Looks at Rudy's toys. Picks up some superhero comics and sits on Rudy's b Then he spies Rudy's COMPOSITION BOOK, picks it up and st reading it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry looks up. Rudy is half-sitting up in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- Just readin' some of your  compositions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you smoking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... Because it's bad. Don't ever  do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know this used to be my room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... (Pause) Do you want it back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy is very relieved. Terry keeps reading. Rudy watches  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you fight in Vietnam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I wasn't even born yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you ever in the army?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father was in the army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Unfortunately he didn't fight  in Vietnam either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you friends with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. We had some friends in  common, I guess... I didn't like him  very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he wasn't very likable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He was always -- He  always had to be better than you at  everything. You know. Like if you  were all playing basketball or  something, everybody's havin' like a  friendly game and he's like ready to  kill somebody if his team didn't  win. Or like if you told like a joke  or a story, he always had to tell a  better one? Kinda gets annoying after  a while. Plus it was pretty scummy  how he split on your mom and you...  He was a prick. Probably still a  prick. Fortunately for you though,  your mom is like, the greatest. So  you had some bad luck and you had  some good luck. (Pause) You mind if I ask you a personal  question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like it here? I mean, in  Scottsville?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. My friends are here...  I like the scenery... I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know, but it's so... There's  nothing to do here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No there isn't, man! It's narrow.  It's dull. It's a dull, narrow town  full of dull, narrow people who don't  know anything except... what things  are like right around here. They  have no perspective whatsoever. No  scope. They might as well be living  in the nineteenth century because  they have no idea what's going on,  and if you try to tell 'em that,  they wanna fuckin' kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry lies on his back and smokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a NOTE on Sammy's chair.

dialogues.speaker: "SAMMY, PLEASE SEE ME
dialogues.text: Sammy, just arrived at work and still in her coat, looks  down at the note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy listens to Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. This doesn't apply to you  directly, Sammy, but I've noticed  that some of the employees have their  PC monitors set with all kinds of  crazy colors... Purple and polka  dots or what have you. And it's not  a big deal, but really, this is a  bank. You know? It's not really  appropriate. So I'm just asking that  people stick to a more quote unquote  normal range of colors in future...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy looks at him blankly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I say, it doesn't really apply  to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, my computer palette's pretty  conservative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mabel is typing angrily at a GRAY SCREEN with BLACK LETTE Sammy walks by. Mabel is so mad she doesn't even look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy sits agitated for a moment. She makes a decision, p up the phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is in his little realty office with two CLIENTS, a hu and wife. He picks up his RINGING PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into phone) Bob Steegerson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On phone) What are you wearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into phone) Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy LAUGHS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry is holding a broom looking up at the ceiling. Sammy passes by and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry taps the broom handle against the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know you have an enormous  leak from the upstairs hall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pokes again. A portion of the ceiling collapses on his head in wet chunks of plaster and muck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, yeah, thanks, I did.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy, in front of the mirror, finishes dolling herself u for her date. O.C. we hear loud banging. Sammy puts on he earrings and goes into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you guys sure you're gonna be  OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy approaches RUDY and TERRY. They are bent over a big nasty trench in the floorboard. There are wood shavings a greasy pipe segments all over, and black smeary smudges o the walls nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is happening here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just -- The problem is that the  pipe is corroded all the way along  the length of the hall. So every  time I put in a new piece it starts  leaking further down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't I just call the plumber?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? He's not gonna do anything  different than what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Happily) Yeah. We're making it worse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No we're not. Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry yanks the wrench and a SPRAY of FILTHY WATER comes of the pipe and splatters the wallpaper and pictures and  Sammy with gritty gray water. She looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you both.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob and Sammy -- cleaned up and wearing a different outfi are bustling out the front door. Terry stands by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, call if there's any problem,  and if I'm not there, I'm either on  my way or on my way back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy gets into her coat. Bob opens the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To TERRY) So lights out at ten... and don't  spend the whole night watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To SAMMY) What's your idea of the whole night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hours tops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob holds the door for Sammy and smiles at her. There is  some confusion about who should go out first. Finally she goes and Bob follows. The atmosphere between them is fair awkward.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Terry and Rudy are watching TV from the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your feeling about Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really know him that well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have bad news for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the remote...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and turns off the TV. They sit there in the sudden sil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. What are we supposed to do  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how to play pool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've played it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE WILD MOOSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Wild Moose is a noisy roadside bar sitting under the  stars. Terry and Rudy get out of the car. Rudy looks  apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think they let kids in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're not allowed to watch any  more TV, so it's this or nothing...  But if we run into any trouble, let  me do the talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry swings the door open.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE WILD MOOSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: POV RUDY: A lot of men and women at the bar or in booths, eating and drinking. Smoky, crowded and very loud. As he  follows Terry through the crowd various patrons notice hi some of the looks are friendly, some blank, some cold, i. what's a kid doing in here? AT THE POOL TABLE: Terry and Rudy stand side by side faci the players and waiting players gathered around the table Terry waves a few bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a hundred bucks here says me  and my nephew can beat anybody in  here. Only we gotta get the next  game 'cause he's gotta be in bed by  ten o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MOMENT LATER: RUDY, very nervous, and the 1st Pool Play are side by side shooting for break. Terry is behind Rudy coaching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just hit it nice and soft... Nice  and soft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hit the balls. Rudy just clips his ball and it doesn go anywhere. 1st Pool Player's ball hits the opposite ban and comes almost all the way back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To TERRY) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn, Rudy. I thought you said  you could play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy doesn't answer. Terry winks at him. A MOMENT LATER: 1ST POOL PLAYER BREAKS -- WHACK! -- The b scatter. Nothing drops. TERRY steps up to the table, chal up his cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, it's all over but the cryin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK CUTS: Of Terry running the table and everyone watch Three-ball in the side. One-ball in the corner. Nine-ball off three cushions and into the corner, and the eleven-ba into the side. Rudy watches him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOB'S APARTMENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob and Sammy sit at Bob's dining room table. The little  bachelor apartment looks pretty good. Tablecloth, candles wine, everything. Bob has just dropped a huge bombshell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob... Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I don't know what to say. I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I know I haven't exactly  been the most... decisive... guy. In  the past... I don't know: I'm tired  of foolin' around. And I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I'm totally... I don't know  what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you could always say "Yes." (Pause) Or you could think about it first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it: I want to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK... Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WILD MOOSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Terry has sunk everything but the eight ball. He leans ov to sink it. It's a fairly easy shot. He lines it up caref and deliberately shoots it so it stops two inches from th corner pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FEW MOMENTS LATER: Terry and Rudy sit side by side watc as the 2nd Pool Player passes back and forth between them and the camera, running the table. "Oohs" and "All rights emit from the spectators. Sudden silence. Then the clack of the balls connecting. A great common GROAN goes up. RUDY looks up at Terry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all yours, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy looks at the TABLE: The eight-ball is two inches off the corner. The cue ball is a few inches away from it. A  piece of cake, for an adult. Rudy looks deeply unconfiden He gets up and tries to line up the eight-ball. Terry is  right next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just make sure to hit it really  gentle. But firm. And hit it a little  low so you get some backspin. Don't  even hit it. Just kiss it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, kiss it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean tap it. Firm but very, very  softly. And don't shoot until you  know it's going in. OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is relatively quiet. Rudy takes a few practice  strokes and then hits the cue ball, straight, but too sof It crawls toward the eight and taps it toward the corner, slower and slower, hangs there, and DROPS. A GENERAL "HEYYY!" GOES UP and everyone claps and cheers. Terry grabs Rudy. Rudy smiles, ecstatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AT THE BAR: Darryl the SHERIFF, in his civvies, drinking pint of beer, notices Rudy and Terry. AT THE POOL TABLE: Terry picks Rudy up and turns him upsi down. Rudy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SAMMY'S HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The house is dark. Terry and Rudy are walking from the ca to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We creamed those guys! We creamed  them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Stopping suddenly) Ssh...! Don't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They listen. A CAR is COMING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They break for the door, Terry fumbling for his key. He g the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go! Go! Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Rudy run inside the house. The lights go on. BOB'S CAR pulls into the DRIVEWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy runs up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, gimme your jacket!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy tries to take his jacket off fast but gets his arm c in the sleeve. He tries to shake it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't get my sleeve out...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They HEAR Bob's CAR DOORS SLAM. Terry makes a comic panic face and leaps up the stairs two at a time. OUTSIDE THE HOUSE: Sammy waves to Bob. Bob waves back as drives off. Sammy goes to the front door, opens it: Terry and Rudy are in a giggly tangled panicked heap at t top of the stairs, shaking Rudy's arm and sleeve, frantic trying to get the jacket off. Sammy comes in. They freeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is going on in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um -- We were just out doing some  star-gazing, and, uh, Rudy lost track  of the time. Which I totally warned  him about. (To Rudy) You are a bad kid.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BATHROOM. LATER
dialogues.text: Rudy is brushing his teeth. Terry pokes his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In a low voice) Hey: I think it's OK. Just don't  tell her where we went, 'cause she'll  be really mad at me. OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Suddenly dark) Hey -- I'm not kidding, Rudy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry gives him a "You better not" look, then leaves. Rud continues brushing his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RUDY'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy is tucking Rudy in, stroking his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know my Mommy used to take  me and Uncle Terry out at night to  look at the constellations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see that one, what's the one --  It looks like a big "W"? Cassiopeia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy comes out of Rudy's room, smiling. It's dark. She s a LIGHT on under TERRY'S DOOR. She walks toward it and st into the TRENCH, falling down violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! Shit!

dialogues.speaker: INT. BATHROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Terry is putting a butterfly Band-Aid on Sammy's wound. I a nasty, bloody gash, just shy of needing stitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a great idea. Why don't you  let me call the plumber?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, does that make you mad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: RAIN patters on the ROOF as Sammy LIMPS back and forth ac the room changing into her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TERRY'S WINDOW. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Terry is smoking pot with his head and shoulders stuck ou the window. RAIN FALLS on his HEAD.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BANK. MORNING
dialogues.text: Early morning. The RAIN is still falling. Only a few cars are in the employee parking lot yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RAIN runs down Brian's office window. BRIAN, in a wet raincoat, turns on his light. A MOMENT LATER: Brian turns on his PC. The SCREEN lights The COLORS are a garish GREEN and ORANGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER: SAMMY and BRIAN are both on their feet. The door i closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian, get off my ass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't change the colors on your  stupid computer screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's all you gotta say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On "that's") There is nothing wrong with the work  I do here. I have been doing just  fine, the whole time before you came  here -- And if you think that riding  people in this petty, ridiculous way  is the way to improve service in  this bank or anywhere else I think  you're out of your mind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say there was. Could I please --  Could I please -- May I respond?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's really all I have to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I respond? (Beat) First of all, I don't appreciate  being spoken to with that kind of  language. That's not the way I talk  to you, and I'd appreciate it if you  wouldn't talk that way to me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second of all, if you say you didn't  change the colors on my computer  screen, then of course I accept your  answer. But you and I are gonna have  to find a way to work together --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's not gonna happen with the  attitude, it's not gonna happen with  the lateness, it's not gonna happen  by fighting me every step of the way --  OK, well not you, you're not late,  but too much of that stuff goes on  around here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not late and I do not have an  attitude -- Well then don't tell me  I'm late if I'm not late!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd really like to finish!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUTSIDE BRIAN'S OFFICE: The whole staff is listening to t muffled raised VOICES from inside the office. MABEL especially is listening guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: The rain falls on Main Street.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ORRIN'S BACKYARD. DAY
dialogues.text: The rain comes down hard on Orrin's construction project. Tarps cover everything. No work today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain comes down on the SHERIFF, looking through the  restaurant WINDOW at SAMMY, eating lunch alone at the cou He goes inside, shakes the rain off himself and goes over her. They start talking. We HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RAIN on the roof makes a sleepy, pleasant country sou TERRY is lying on the sofa, smoking a joint, watching TV, a funk. O.C. we LOUD BANGING ON THE PIPES. LATER: A YOUNG PLUMBER, about Terry's age, comes thumping down the stairs and goes into the living room, carrying h toolbox. Terry looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, you're all set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry glares at him. The plumber turns and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BUS STOP. DAY
dialogues.text: RUDY is WAITING in a doorway for Terry. He is wet and col The RAIN pours down.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BANK. DAY
dialogues.text: Brian is showing his wife, NANCY, the bank. He is very  solicitous of her, nervously introducing her to the emplo who are not responding very warmly. Nancy is not in a war mood either; she's very testy with Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Chuck. Chuck, this is my  wife, Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mabel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAMMY, at her desk, watches Brian and Nancy make their  progress through the bank. Nobody is being very friendly, and Brian suddenly seems awkward and vulnerable. Brian an Nancy reach Sammy's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Sammy, our lending officer.  Sammy, this is my wife, Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Friendly) Hi. It's nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian -- I gotta sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure -- Let's go in my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances nervously at Sammy as he leads Nancy away from her desk and toward his office. He murmurs something to N who responds in a low but very testy voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She roughly pulls her arm away from his. Sammy watches th go into his office.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: Rudy trudges resolutely through the pouring rain toward t center of town. He is completely drenched.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BRIAN'S OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: Sammy knocks on Brian's open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy sees to her left, down the hallway --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy is at the end of the hall, drenched and shivering, b cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. EMPLOYEE PARKING LOT. DAY
dialogues.text: Rudy is in the car, somewhat dried off, waiting. Sammy an Terry stand in the employee entrance doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm glad you guys are getting  along so well -- like, you have no  idea -- but if I can't rely on you  to remember to get him once a day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And what are you doing taking him  to play pool in the middle of the  night, and then telling him to lie  to me about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. SAMMY'S CAR/CAROL'S DRIVEWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Terry and Rudy pull up in front of the driveway. Terry is a silent rage. The rain has let up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to Carol's house and  I'm going home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't I come with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if you're such a baby you  gotta tell your Mommy about us playin'  pool when I totally asked you not  to, and I gotta listen to her shit  all day, then you're goin' to the  baby-sitter's so you can stay at the  baby house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I didn't tell her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? Don't even fuckin'  talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans over Rudy roughly and pushes open the door. Rudy gets out of the car and marches down the long driveway. H bursts into tears. Terry watches him go, then drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy walks through the empty bank hall and into Brian's  office. Brian is at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're working late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did your wife like the bank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fine. She wasn't feeling so great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I don't mean -- She's not ill.  She's just... I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. She's pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can make you kind of cranky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm sorry we've been stepping  on each other's toes -- I -- I'm not  actually that bad a guy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I am too... I know you're not,  Brian, but you're driving everybody  crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I -- I'm just trying to do my  best here -- And I'm gettin' it from  all sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway... We'll work it out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I could use a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could use a tranquilizer.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PUB. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Brian and Sammy sit at a table in the corner of the dimly lit pub. It's a medium noisy place with various locals  drinking beers and eating hamburgers and chicken dinners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last I heard, Rudy's Dad was living  over in Auburn. But that was last  year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be so tough raising a kid on  your own... Although I'm beginning  to get the idea my wife wouldn't  mind a crack at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... It's just the hormones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no, it isn't. But never mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress brings them two boilermakers. SAMMY and BRIAN Thanks. She leaves. Sammy and Brian pick up their shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here's to improved employee- management relations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They click shot glasses and drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't judge all of Scottsville  by the people in that bank, believe  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- Let's -- Let's not talk about  the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.
