dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just forget about the bank for  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sip their drinks, smiling. Sammy looks at him  appraisingly.

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. BRIAN'S CAR/WOODED ROAD. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy and Brian are making out in the front seat of his c This goes on for a while, getting heavier and heavier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to tell me who changed  the colors on my computer screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start kissing again in the cramped space. Brian bang his head. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back and away from the car. The sodden trees spou faucets of water down on the car.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The kitchen is dark. Sammy comes in, her hair a little we and turns on the light. She goes to the telephone. There's a NOTE in Terry's handwriting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy jumps, startled. Terry is in the kitchen doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nowhere. I had dinner with my boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of a late dinner, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. How was Rudy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the plumber come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, the fucking plumber came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry -- Give me a break!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. I'm just tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to smoke some pot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I don't. Why, you got some?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PORCH. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy and Terry stand side by side on the porch, passing joint back and forth. It has stopped raining but the tree and roof are still dripping. The crickets are chirping lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... Bob asked me to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. (Pause) Are you going to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. If he'd've asked me  this time last year I would have  probably said yes. But the minute he  said it, I don't know, I felt like  somebody was trying to strangle me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... bad sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (Pause) Plus, Terry... (Whispers) I fucked my boss...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know! And his wife is six months  pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Sammy...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes her the joint. She declines. He puffs away. The water drips off the porch and the crickets chirp. She put her head on his shoulder. He puts one arm around her and  puffs away with the joint in his free hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry, I'm sorry I got so mad before.  I just don't want him, you know --  terrified of "telling," if there's --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, well, that's not really his  problem, Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really? What's his problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His problem is that he's like totally  sheltered because you treat him like  he's three, instead of eight, so  that's how he behaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? And how do you think he  should behave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he shouldn't have to run and  tell his Mommy every time he does  something she might not like, for  one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh. And what do you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On "and") I mean I took him to play pool! It  was a little clandestine thing we  did for fun! It wasn't like a big  secret, I mean who cares? I was  actually trying to be nice to him.  But he's so freaked out that he  disobeyed your orders that he has to  fuckin' squeal on me and I have to  listen to your fuckin' shit all day  when I didn't even fuckin' do  anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, he didn't tell me  anything: Darryl did. OK? Second of  all, I don't really give a shit if  you took him to play pool: I was mad  at you because you left him standing  at the bus stop in the rain. But no,  I don't want you telling him not to  squeal, because I don't want him put  in that position!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Losing ground) Well... that... is a perfect example  of what I'm talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are in idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand apart now. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darryl told you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand there. The rain gutters drip.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BANK. MORNING
dialogues.text: Sammy, coat on, arrives at her desk and puts her purse do There's a NOTE on her CHAIR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRACKING SAMMY, coat off, carrying a stack of folders, as she walks from her desk, around the corner, down the hall past a couple of employees and to BRIAN'S OPEN DOOR. She  taps on it. Brian is at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, good morning. Could you get  the door?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUTSIDE THE OFFICE: Sammy shuts the door. MABEL and DORIS standing near the door, look at each other: i.e., Sammy's trouble again. INSIDE THE OFFICE: Sammy stands by the closed door. Brian comes out around his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen -- I just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian kisses her. She drops her folders and they make out against the door. OUTSIDE THE OFFICE: The employees click away at their PCs Mabel exchanges a quiet word with Chuck. INSIDE THE OFFICE: Brian has Sammy pressed against the wa with her skirt hiked up and is trying to get both of thei underwear out of the way. It's not so easy in their offic clothes. Sammy tears away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian, that's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIAN falls back, breathless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lunges at her again. They kiss some more. OUTSIDE THE OFFICE. A MOMENT LATER: Sammy comes out of th office, more or less composed, carrying her folders. She  heads down the hall past the other employees, including M and surreptitiously readjusts her scrunched-up underwear.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DAWSON'S. DAY
dialogues.text: Sammy and Bob sit at lunch. Sammy is picking at her food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're awfully quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... Have you thought at all about  what I said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I've been thinking about  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... Any decisions? Or -- do you  still want to think about it some  more...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I mean -- I don't know, Bob.  I mean, we haven't exactly been going  steady the last few months, if you  know what I mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, no, I know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and then we see each other twice  and you suddenly say you want to get  married? I mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're right, you're right --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I... Maybe this is...  Last year I sort of thought you were  possibly interested in that... idea...  but I was the one who, you know,  wasn't "ready" at that point -- So  that's why I thought things kind of  slowed down with us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make me feel bad for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Bristling) I don't want you to feel bad for me.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy, Terry and Rudy are all watching TV. Sammy and Rudy are in pajamas. Nobody's happy and nobody's talking. The PHONE RINGS. Sammy goes to it and picks up, surprised because of the hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On phone) It's Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy turns away and lowers her voice so Terry and Rudy w overhear her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian. Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian is on the pay phone outside a gas station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm buying milk. I just thought I'd  say hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE CUT BETWEEN THEM. Sammy doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I know it's probably too late,  but is there any way you can come  out for a little while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian, I think you're going crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I am. Can you meet me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, OK.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: SAMMY comes down the stairs, fully dressed, into the livi room, where Terry and Rudy are still watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um -- I have to go out for a minute.  Do you want anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have to go out for a little  while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have to go to Mabel's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, Rudy? It's personal.  This is a personal matter that has  to do with Mabel. I just have to go  see her for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry gives Sammy a look like, "You've got to be kidding. Sammy tries to shush him with a conspiratorial look back. She goes out. LATER. Terry and Rudy sit in front of the TV, alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. Listen. I'm sorry I said you  squealed on me. I was totally out of  line, and I really owe you an apology. (Pause) Did you hear what I said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Staring at the TV) I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy drives, listening to music. She shakes her head at  herself.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOTEL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy's car and Brian's car are parked side by side outsi a roadside motel.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MOTEL ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: In the motel room, Sammy and Brian, half-clothed, make lo rather hurriedly on top of the unmade creaky bed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOTEL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Outside the motel, Sammy and Brian get into their respect cars and start their motors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy drives in the other direction. She breaks into a sm and then she laughs. Then she stops.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S BEDROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy lies awake plagued by guilty feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy heads toward the little white church building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RON the MINISTER and Sammy drink coffee in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Gently) What's on your mind, Sammy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, a lot. But principally... I  was just wondering if you had an  opinion. If you know someone, in  your family, or just someone you  really care about, and they just  can't seem to get ahold of  themselves...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: The SUN SHINES on Main Street.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SPORTING GOODS STORE. DAY
dialogues.text: Rudy watches wide-eyed as Terry places on the sales count two rods and reels, a bunch of lures, two fishing hats, a box of swivels, a knife and a fish scaler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who this is for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, my little friend. (To the saleslady) Hello. We're going fishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy, Terry and Rudy are all putting away the groceries. Everybody seems to be getting along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a new rod and reel, five lures,  I got a hat, I got a knife and I got  a fish scaler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.C., the DOORBELL RINGS. Sammy starts to move toward the door, but Terry is closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. FRONT DOOR. DAY
dialogues.text: Terry opens the door. It's Ron, the minister, in his civv

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FRONT YARD. DAY
dialogues.text: Rudy is playing basketball by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry, Sammy and RON sit in the living room. Sammy and Ro are drinking coffee. Through the window we see occasional glimpses of Rudy playing basketball in the backyard. Ther is a heavy silence in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I'm not really sure why you're  here, Ron. I mean, I realize I haven't  exactly been a model citizen since I  got here, but compared to how things  have been goin' for me lately, I  thought I was doing pretty well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I also find it kind of  discouraging that you seem to think  I need some kind of spiritual  counseling or what have you, so much  so that you're willing to disregard  the fact that I don't believe in any  of this stuff at all --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I didn't mean to discourage  you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it's really kind of insulting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I say something here? (Pause) Sammy asked me to come and talk to  you, because it's her opinion that  you're not gonna find what you're  looking for the way you're looking  for it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would she know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm really not here to try to  get you to do anything, or to believe  anything. And I'll tell you the same  thing I told her, which is that as  far as I'm concerned the only way  she can help you is by her example --  by trying to be a model for you, by  the way she lives her life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that doesn't mean she's supposed  to be a saint, either, if that's  what you're smiling about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't realize I was smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Terry, a lot of people  come to see me with all kinds of  problems. Drugs, alcohol, marital  problems, sexual problems, health  problems --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great job you got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I like it. Because even in  this little town, I feel like what I  do is very connected with the real  center of people's lives. I'm not  saying I'm always Mr. Effective, but  I don't feel like my life is off to  the side of what's important. You  know? I don't feel my happiness and  comfort are based on closing my eyes  to trouble within myself or trouble  in other people. I don't feel like a  negligible little scrap, floating  around in some kind of empty void,  with no sense of connectedness to  anything around me except by virtue  of whatever little philosophies I  can scrape together on my own...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you, Terry: Do you think  your life is important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean -- Like, me personally, my  individual life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I'm not sure -- What do you  mean? It's important to me. I guess.  And like, to my, you know, the people  who care about me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But do you think it's important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think it's important in the  scheme of things? Not just because  it's yours, or because you're  somebody's brother. Because I don't  really get the impression that you  do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think... I don't  particularly think anybody's life  has any particular importance besides  whatever -- you know -- whatever we  arbitrarily give it. Which is fine.  I mean we might as well... I think  I'm as important as anybody else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know: A lot of what you're  saying has a real appeal to me, Ron.  A lot of the stuff they told us when  we were kids... But I don't want to  believe something or not believe it  because I might feel bad. I want to  believe it because I think it's true  or not... I'd like to think that my  life is important... Or that it's  connected to something important...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, isn't there any way for you to  believe that without calling it God,  or religion, or whatever term it is  you object to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I believe that.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy, Terry and Rudy are all eating dinner. Terry is dri a beer. His mood is dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Sammy, what example will you be  setting for us tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Terry, Sammy and Rudy are watching TV. Terry has another  beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time are we getting up to go  fishing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going fishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should go fishing with  Father Ron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to go fishing with Father  Ron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not takin' you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy starts to say something to Terry, stops herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take you, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy and Terry are in the hallway. Sammy holds a stack o folded sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I realize that you're mad at me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Deadpan) I'm not mad at you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but he didn't do anything to you.  And you cannot promise a little boy  that you're gonna --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (On "boy") ...I just, you know, after all that  religious conversation, I just  realized it's probably not so good  for him to be spending so much time  with someone like me who doesn't  believe his life is important in the  scheme of things --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Practically choking) Listen. (Pause) I am sure, if you put your mind to  it, you can think of some other way  of getting back at me besides this.  So would you please just give it  some thought, and take him fishing  tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would, Sammy, I just don't think  it'd be good for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You suck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws the sheets at him and storms away. Terry walks through the living room and OUT the front door, SLAMMING behind him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy sits by the phone in her bathrobe. She picks it up DIALS. INTERCUT: BRIAN'S LIVING ROOM. NANCY, watching TV on the  sofa with Brian, picks up the RINGING PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into the phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAMMY HANGS UP. She gets up, walks around, sits down agai Picks up the phone and DIALS. It RINGS. INTERCUT: BOB'S KITCHENETTE. Bob, making a sandwich for  himself, picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into the phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAMMY HANGS UP. Pause. She sweeps the TELEPHONE and ANSWE MACHINE OFF the nightstand. Pause. She calms down and put them back. The ancient answering machine is CLICKING  convulsively. She WHACKS IT and it stops.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHURCH. DAY
dialogues.text: The congregation is coming out of the church and milling  around at the steps. SAMMY, with Rudy at her side, is say good-bye to some neighbors. She watches pregnant NANCY an BRIAN go down the steps. POV SAMMY: Beyond Brian and Nancy, TERRY pulls up at the  curb in her car. He rummages around and produces FISHING  RODS which he waves, somewhat sheepishly. REVERSE: At top speed, Rudy runs away from Sammy and the  church, toward Terry and the car. Terry and Sammy exchang look from the distance.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RECTORY. DAY
dialogues.text: Services are over. Everyone has gone home.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RON'S OFFICE. LATER
dialogues.text: Sammy sits with Ron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway... I don't know what the  church's position is on adultery and  fornication these days, but I felt  really hypocritical not saying  anything to you about it before,  so... What is the official position  on that stuff these days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... it's a sin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good: I think it should be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but we don't tend to focus on  that aspect of it, right off the bat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it was better when you came in  and they screamed at you for having  sex with your married boss, and were  really mean to you, and told you  what a terrible thing it was. Maybe  it'd be better if you told me how  I'm endangering my immortal soul,  and if I don't quit I'm going to  burn in hell. Don't you ever think  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a lot better than all  this "Why do you think you're in  this situation" psychological bullshit  you hear all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... Why do you think you're in  this situation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel sorry for them. (Pause) Isn't that ridiculous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron shrugs: i.e., "not necessarily."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry and Rudy are side by side on a small footbridge ove wide running stream, fishing. The sunlight slants through the canopy of trees; the birds are chattering; it's gorge and peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never been so bored in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... We really shoulda been out  here around seven or eight A.M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. The birds sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was my father a good fisherman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, your father was good at all  that stuff. He knew everything about  the woods, everything about fishing,  everything about hunting and  everything about cars. If he wasn't  such a pain in the ass he would've  been a lot of fun to be around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's nicer now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you know? Did you ever  meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you ever curious to meet him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he doesn't live very far from  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he lived in Alaska.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I lived in Alaska. Your dad  lives in Auburn. Far as I know. (Pause) We could look him up in the phone  book. Wanna try?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK -- But -- I'm sure I don't have  to say this, but I'm not kidding,  man: Don't -- tell -- your -- mother.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOB'S APARTMENT. DAY
dialogues.text: BOB is standing by his kitchenette, extremely nervous. Sa sits on his sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to go for a walk, or a  drive? It's really nice out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm not gonna stay long. Bob, I  don't want to get married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've really thought about it a lot,  and if you had asked me last year  I'm sure I would have said yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not sure it would have been  a good idea then either. I'm going  through a really hard time right now  and I just think that getting engaged  to you or anyone would be just about  the stupidest most self-destructive  thing I could possibly do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I really think you have to grow  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how about we fix up my  personality some other time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. (Pause) I really hope we can still be friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quietly sarcastic) Oh, yes, me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him miserably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob... This is so crazy... I mean...  I don't even understand why you... I  don't even get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to say? Everything  you said about me was true, Sammy. I  was just a big chickenshit jerk, and  now I'm payin' the price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes over to him. He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Sammy, I love you. I  wish I could say it in a more  interesting way. I just -- I love  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- I mean -- I love you too --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his arms around her and kisses her. She responds  very warmly. Just as things are heating up, she suddenly  remembers something and jolts away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go. I'm sorry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you have to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Off the top of her  head) I'm supposed to -- I gotta get Mabel  back her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I don't understand. How are  we leaving things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, I don't know. Call me later.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MOTEL. DAY
dialogues.text: Brian sits on the edge of one of the beds watching some  daytime Sunday show on the motel TV. There is a knock at door. He gets up, turns off the TV and opens the door. It Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm so late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was just about to give up on  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- maybe it would've been better  if you had...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes into the room and starts walking around briskly and nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean -- Look, I don't mean to be  unsympathetic about your domestic  situation, whatever it is, but I'm  just beginning to think that if people  tried a little harder to stick to  their commitments and started taking  a little responsibility for their  actions, they might end up having a  lot less trouble generally. That's  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that's what I've been trying to  tell you guys at the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I really don't think I can do  this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MOTEL ROOM. LATER
dialogues.text: Brian and Sammy lie under the starchy sheets. Brian's eye are shut. Sammy is very upset with herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is incredible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry and Rudy drive along. Terry looks down at Rudy and  smiles. Rudy is tense and won't look at him. OVER TERRY AND RUDY'S SHOULDERS as Terry drives slowly pa dilapidated little houses in a very depressed residential area. Terry is scanning the house numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should call first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- We're right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls up outside a small, plain, run-down ranch-style  house with a lot of junk out front, and gets out of the c Rudy stays in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy gets out of the car and comes around. Terry waits fo him, and then they walk up to the front door. The buzzer  says "KOLINSKI."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His last name is Kolinski?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Ring the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy pushes the doorbell. They wait. There's some noise i and some voices. The sound of WALKING. THE DOOR OPENS. JANIE, a tired-looking young woman around Terry's age, opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. We're looking for Rudy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who should I say is calling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says an old friend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUDY SR. appears behind Janie. He's around thirty, wiry,  dressed in jeans and an old shirt. He doesn't look good. recognizes Terry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Rudy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy Sr. sees Rudy, who is looking up at him. His face fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To JANIE) Hi, I'm Terry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Rudy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy, meet Rudy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy Sr. looks away, shaking his head. JANIE moves away f the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just be in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie goes into the kitchen. Rudy Sr. watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK if we come in for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean what am I doin' --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy Sr. starts walking toward Terry to make him go back the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you step away from the door  please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we just wanna --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you step away from the door  please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all go outside. Rudy Sr. pulls the door closed behin him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doin' here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted the kid to see you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now he saw me. (He looks at Rudy) Now you saw me. OK? (To Terry) Now would you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you are really --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look: I'm tryin' to be polite. So  would you just take off? It's OK:  Just take off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanna --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what you're doin'? Just  get outta here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, man? You're still a  fuckin' asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an asshole? Get outta here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy Sr. shoves Terry. Terry belts him, and suddenly they are throwing wild punches at each other. Rudy goes sprawl in the dirt. Terry knocks Rudy Sr. down and starts pummeling him bruta Janie comes out of the house and jumps on his back, tryin to pull him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your fuckin' hands off him...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry throws Janie off him, grabs Rudy Sr. again and resu beating him up. Janie jumps back on top of him. Two neighbors run toward the melee to break it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FEW MOMENTS LATER: The cops have arrived. The 1ST COP i talking to Rudy and Janie. The 2ND COP is talking to Terr Rudy Sr.'s face looks puffy and beaten up. A 3RD COP stan apart with Rudy, who is watching the whole thing. WE CUT  rapidly and jerkily through this section:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're not the boy's legal  guardian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know if that's my kid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just showed up! We never seen  them before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to know his sister --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just came down here to talk to the  guy and all of a sudden he starts  shovin' me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen up. Listen up. You're gonna  have to step back and just calm down --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To RUDY SR.) You're a lyin' fuckin' piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To TERRY) You're gonna have to step back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a right to protect ourselves.  What else do you need to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MOMENT LATER: The 2ND COP puts handcuffs on Terry. Rudy watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now give me your right hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is such bullshit. He started  the whole thing and you're arresting  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen up. Now -- Listen up! Stop  talkin'. Terry, stop talkin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MOMENT LATER: As the 3RD COP walks Rudy to one cop car, Rudy watches the 2ND COP guide the HANDCUFFED TERRY into other car. Rudy gets in the back of the car and looks out at RUDY SR and JANIE talking to the 1ST COP. Rudy Sr. is looking at over the 1st cop's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- idea where we might be able to  contact his mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, because he's not my Goddamn kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop cars' doors slam first on Terry and then on Rudy.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MOTEL ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The room is dark. Sammy and Brian are asleep, half under covers. SAMMY WAKES with a START.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Startled awake) What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy looks at the clock radio. 9:20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my gosh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FEW MOMENTS LATER: Sammy and Brian are on opposite side of the bed, getting dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you know, Nancy's gonna be gone  for the rest of the week...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know... Brian...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't want to... I mean,  couldn't we just... I mean, could we  give it a rest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um -- Yeah. Sure. If you want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean... I just think... I don't  know: We had a great little fling.  You know? Let's not push it. (Pause) I mean, is that OK? I just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure. OK. You're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are we still friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Nods tersely) Mm hm. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Good...!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SAMMY'S HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The crickets are chattering. The phone is ringing inside house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE is ringing on the NIGHTSTAND. The battered answ machine CLICKS convulsively but does not pick up.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S KITCHEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy is on the phone in her bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around two o'clock this afternoon...  Yeah, a ninety three Toyota Tercel.  New York plates V127AC... Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy, dressed now, opens the door for BOB. She is very  anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming over. I just want  to have a car handy just in case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy is on the phone. Bob sits at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into the phone) Well -- what about other towns?...  Yes! Yes! I called the highway patrol  four times... Well what am I supposed  to do all night?

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S LIVING ROOM. LATER
dialogues.text: Sammy and Bob sit silently in the living room, waiting. S is smoking. The CLOCK READS 12:40. Sammy is going crazy w anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SAMMY'S HOUSE. MORNING
dialogues.text: The PHONE rings inside the house as the early morning sun slants through the trees around the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RINGING PHONE wakes BOB, on the sofa in his clothes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and Sammy, half asleep on top of her bed, also in her  clothes. She GRABS the PHONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob drives Sammy along the highway. She stares out the wi She turns and watches Bob drive for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BANK. DAY
dialogues.text: Brian walks through the morning bank activity and stops a Mabel's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone hear from Sammy this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Well, if anyone ever hears  from her ever again, will you let me  know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. AUBURN POLICE STATION. DAY
dialogues.text: On the steps of the police station, Sammy, Rudy and Bob w as Sheriff Darryl shakes hands with the Auburn Sheriff. T Auburn Sheriff goes inside. Darryl comes over to Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna be all right... We got on  the phone and talked to Rudy Sr. a  little bit and he's calmed down,  just wants to forget about the whole  thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darryl, I really appreciate this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff nods, but he's not thrilled to be here.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SAMMY'S LIVING ROOM. DUSK
dialogues.text: The PHONE IS RINGING. Sammy comes in the front door, Terr and Rudy behind her. She snaps on the lights, hurries to phone and picks up. Behind her, Rudy goes upstairs and Terry plunks down on t sofa and turns on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened to you today,  lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SAMMY is about to answer, but she just HANGS UP instead. BRIAN is stunned into sheer gaping fury. Feverishly he ha up and dials again. It RINGS. Sammy picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fired!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GOOD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up again.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RUDY'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy is tucking Rudy into bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything you want to ask  me, about your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that wasn't my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't him. I heard him tell  the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- Rudy -- that was him. But that  was him. I wish it wasn't, but it  was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Very quiet) No it wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy. Yes it was. Your father's name  is Rudy Kolinski. He lives in  Auburn...

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy comes out of Rudy's room, shutting the door softly. HEAR the TV going downstairs. She stands at the top of th stairs for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Terry is watching TV on the sofa with his feet up on the  coffee table. Sammy comes down the stairs and into the li room. He keeps watching TV. She doesn't sit. She is tremb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you turn that off for a minute  please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns off the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to say anything, Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean I don't think you should live  here anymore. I don't think you know  how to behave around an eight-year- old and I don't know how to make you  stop, so I think you shouldn't live  here. I don't know what else to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to behave around an  eight-year-old?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you don't know how to behave  around an eight-year-old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you out of your MIND!?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you just listen to me. I may not  be the greatest mother in the world,  but I'm doing the best I know how.  And he doesn't need you to rub his  face in shit because you think it's  good for him. He's going to find out  the world is a horrible place and  that people suck soon enough, and  without any help from you. Believe  me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy tries to get ahold of herself. Her voice is shaking

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should get your own place.  I thought, if you want, you could --  I'll be glad to help you out  financially --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Get my own place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean in Scottsville?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I do that? Why don't I  just leave, period?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quietly) Well... If that's what you want to  do, that's fine. But that's not what  I'm saying. You are a very important  person to Rudy, and you are the most  important person to me. But I'm saying  that I can't take any more of this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I thought -- maybe you could sell  your half of the house to me, and I  could pay you whatever it is over a  certain amount of time, and that way --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you know what? I'll just go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the TV back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Very quietly) Well -- that's not what I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry shrugs and watches TV.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TERRY'S ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Terry is packing his bag. Rudy is watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I just want to get out  of this town. And if you've got any  sense when you get old enough you'll  get out of here too. Your Mom's gonna  live in this town for the rest of  her life, and you know why? Because  she thinks she has to. Don't ask me  why, but that's the truth. She thinks  there's all these things she has to  do, but you want to know one thing  about your Mom? She's a bigger fuck- up than I ever was. I mean, I know I  messed up. You think I enjoy getting  thrown in jail because I wanted you  to face that prick your Dad like a  little man and see what kind of a  guy he is? I know I got a little  carried away, and I lost my temper  just a little bit -- which is not  the end of the world either, by the  way, just for future reference --And  now she's kickin' me out of my own  house because -- you know, because I  fucked up a little bit. Which I  totally admit. I was like -- totally  ready to admit that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is finished stuffing his clothes into his backpack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could go with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thanks, man. But I, uh, I can't  really take care of you.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sammy is flipping channels on the TV. The DOORBELL RINGS. She is surprised. She gets up. Terry comes thundering dow the stairs, carrying his backpack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm just gonna stay at Ray's  till I take off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well, that's what I wanna do,  so --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well but -- Are you gonna come back  to say good-bye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I'm just gonna take off. I'll  see you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry opens the door. RAY is there. Terry closes the door behind him. Sammy listens to the PICKUP TRUCK DRIVE OFF. sound FADES.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RAY'S HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Terry is bunked down on Ray's horrible sofa. In the b.g., there is a light on in the bedroom. Terry fluffs his pill and shuts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SAMMY'S HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Dressed for work and school, Sammy and Rudy walk to the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. I know you're upset about Uncle  Terry leaving, and so am I. But he's  just not in control of himself, and  I don't want him hurting your feelings  anymore -- or mine. And you may not  like it, but that's how it's gotta  be. OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't care. I don't care either.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BRIAN'S OFFICE. DAY
dialogues.text: Sammy sits in front of Brian's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I'm sorry you're havin' all  this trouble...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you made a pretty good speech to  me yesterday about people sticking  to their commitments...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... you made a commitment to  this bank, Sammy. To this job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I'd --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And to working things out with this  tough new son of a bitch boss of  yours. And whatever might have passed  between us after hours doesn't mean  you just walk away from that  commitment -- yeah, even when you  have a legitimate family emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry I didn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is why I think in the calm  cold light of day, we should both  think real hard about whether or not  you really want to continue on here  at Merchants National Trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you're not happy, I'm not happy,  it's not good for you and it sure as  heck isn't good for the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know you're the worst manager  we've ever had?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Sammy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By far the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't wanna trade insults with  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't want to be fired, Brian.  I've been working here for seven  years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if I were you I'd be a little  nervous about firing an employee I  just had an affair with. OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's -- Don't threaten me, Sammy:  I'm not threatening you. I -- It's  just an area I think we should  explore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not thr -- You explore it. I'm  going back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads for the door, stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and I have to pick up Rudy today  because there's no one else to do  it. But I'll find someone as soon as  I have time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Fine. Why don't you just take  over the whole bank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy hesitates in the doorway. This thought has never  occurred to her before. She goes out.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LUNCH PLACE. DAY
dialogues.text: THROUGH THE WINDOW we see Sammy and Bob having lunch. Sam watches him eat, full of mixed feelings about him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Sammy is at the stove, making pancakes. She puts a last  pancake onto Rudy's plate and brings it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I called where Uncle Terry  said he was gonna stay, and there  was no answer, so I don't know if  he's still in town or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy? Are you not speaking to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry you're so mad at me,  but I only did what I thought I had  to do, and I hope you don't stay mad  at me for the rest of your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the maple syrup and pours it on the pancakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy, that's too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps pouring. She grabs the bottle from him and upset some of the dishes on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta cut this out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know what you're talking  about! There was nothing else I could  do! I can't explain it better than  that, but you can't go on like this  because you don't know anything about  it and you don't know what you're  doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Frightened) OK, I'm sorry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you to be sorry, I just  want you to STOP IT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will! I will! I'm stopping, I'm  sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes around the table to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? I'm stopping! I'm not doing it.  See? I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's very alarmed. Sammy looks at him for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CEMETERY. DAY
dialogues.text: Terry walks through the little cemetery gate and makes hi way up the hill through the tombstones. He reaches his  parents' graves. He looks at the tombstones for a moment. puts his hand on top of one headstone, then the other. He sits down and smokes. He looks up at the SKY. It's a  beautiful deep blue sky dotted with billowy white clouds. He looks out over the hilly scenery. After a moment he sh his head a few times. He doesn't even know he's doing it. sits there.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RAY'S HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: The PHONE IS RINGING as Terry walks into the house. He wa past it, to the fridge, gets a beer and opens it. It KEEP RINGING. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into phone) Ray's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy is at her desk on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE CUT BETWEEN THEM. Terry doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know if you left yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I'm leavin' tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- What time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a bus at nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- Can I -- I'd like to see you  before you go. I mean, can I give  you a lift? Or do you want to have  breakfast or anything? And I think  Rudy would really like to say good- bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- I don't know... I mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry, you can't just leave like  this. I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right. I'll come by  in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- But just -- We have to  be out of the house by eight, so --  I don't want to tell Rudy you're  coming unless you really think you  can make it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- No -- I'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. MORNING
dialogues.text: Sammy is clearing the breakfast dishes. Rudy is finishing his cereal. The clock reads 7:50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should get your sneakers on.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOUSE. A MOMENT LATER
dialogues.text: Sammy comes out and looks up and down the road.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. A FEW MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Rudy sits in the living room in his baseball jacket. His  knapsack is on the floor beside him. He looks at the CLOC 8:06. Sammy comes into the living room and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetie, I'm sorry, we have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't I miss school one day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They HEAR the PICKUP PULL UP OUTSIDE, O.C. Rudy gets up  immediately.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE HOUSE. A MOMENT LATER
dialogues.text: Terry jumps out of RAY'S PICKUP. Sammy opens the front do and Rudy runs out toward Terry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how's it goin', man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy stops short in front of Terry. Terry looks at Sammy, the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: EXT./INT. CAR. DAY
dialogues.text: The car stops across the street from the BUS. The LAST KI are getting in. SAMMY HONKS for the bus driver, and Sammy Terry and Rudy all get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Rudy... If I write you a letter,  will you write me back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, well, that's gonna be pretty  nice for you, because I write a pretty  Goddamn interesting letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Well, say good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudy hugs Terry. Terry hugs him back. He is suddenly over and presses his lips to the top of Rudy's head. Rudy walks to the BUS and gets on. The bus pulls away. Alone now, Sammy and Terry are not that comfortable. He m to get back in the car, and she does the same.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BENCH. DAY
dialogues.text: Sammy and Terry sit on a bench near the bus stop. Terry's backpack is by his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need some cash for the bus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I got a few bucks... Aren't you  gonna be late for work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- Yeah. That's OK. (Pause) Terry, I don't even know where you're  going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, I didn't really have a  concrete plan yet. I have to go back  to Worcester and get my stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, are you gonna try to see that  girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... Yeah... You know... Thought  maybe I'd try to show my face... Let  her brother have a crack at me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I don't want anyone to have a  crack at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just kidding. I just thought...  Just thought I'd check up on her... (Pause) Anyway, after that, I don't really  know. I've been thinking about Alaska  a lot. I still got some friends out  there. I don't really know. Anyway,  I'll write you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Sammy. Of course I will. You  know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is gonna happen to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing too bad... But I gotta tell  you, I know things didn't work out  too well this time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Terry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but it's always really good to  know that wherever I am, whatever  stupid shit I'm doing, you're back  at my home, rooting for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do root for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts crying, and looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Sammy. Everything's gonna  be all right... Comparatively... And  I'll be back this way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I'm never gonna see you  again...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you will, Sammy. You never  have to worry about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't go till you know where  you're going. Please...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do know where I'm going. I'm going  to Worcester and I'm gonna try to  see that girl. And then depending on  what happens there, I thought I'd  try to see if there's any work for  me out West. And if there is, I'm  gonna head out there for the summer  and try to make some money. And if  there isn't, I'll figure something  else out. Maybe I'll stay around the  East. I don't know... I really liked  it in Alaska. It was really beautiful.  You just -- It made me feel good.  And before things got so messed up I  was doin' pretty well out there.  Seriously. But I couldn't stay here  long, Sammy: I don't want to live  here. But I'm gonna stay in touch.  And I'll be back. 'Cause I want to  see you and I want to see Rudy. I'll  come home for Christmas. How about  that? We'll have Christmas together. (Pause) Come on, Sammy. You can trust me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still looking down, Sammy shakes her head, tears leaking  down her cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Sammy... Look at me... Look  at me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Sammy... Remember when we were  kids, remember what we always used  to say to each other . . .? (Pause) Remember when we were kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I do...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws her arms around his neck. He pats her gently.

dialogues.speaker: INT./EXT. BUS. DAY
dialogues.text: The DOORS OPEN and Terry comes up the steps and into the  bus. Outside, Sammy watches him pay the driver and move  through the bus toward his seat. The BUS DOORS CLOSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sammy waves till the BUS DRIVES all the way down MAIN STR turns a corner and is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry, in his seat, turns forward and watches the view go by. He smiles a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morning sunlight flickers through the windshield into the car as Sammy drives along toward work. She passes the TOWN HALL CLOCK and sees that it's 9:20. She dries her damp cheek with a forearm and rolls down he window to let the morning breeze blow through. Squaring her shoulders a little, she drives through town a slow and easy pace.
